newsitem.title: CHINA: SHANGHAI COPPER FUTURES END DOWN ON PROFIT-TAKING.
newsitem.headline: SHANGHAI COPPER FUTURES END DOWN ON PROFIT-TAKING.

text.p: Shanghai copper futures ended mostly down on Tuesday on profit-taking from retail investors, triggered by overnight losses on the London Metal Exchange (LME), traders said.
LME copper fell prey to liquidation on Monday afternoon, briefly tested $2,270 and ended down $14 at $2,274 per tonne.
London analysts said LME copper had run out of steam and would probably test chart support at $2,270 per tonne on Tuesday.
In Shanghai, the most actively traded December 1997 contract ended at 21,300 yuan ($2,569) per tonne, losing 280 yuan. It opened at an intraday high of 21,500 and hit a low of 21,270 yuan per tonne.
August was unchanged at 20,800, September fell 200 to 20,900, October 220 to 21,180, November 280 to 21,300 and the January 1997 contract 310 to 21,240 yuan per tonne.
Combined volume fell to 32,310 tonnes from 59,120 tonnes.
Copper opened lower but mostly at intraday highs and fell steadily before most contracts closing near lows.
Traders said some investors took advantage of the LME losses to cash in but further sharp falls seemed unlikely in the next few days.
"LME losses triggered profit-taking but volume was thin, indicating many investors were still staying on the sidelines," one trader said.
"Copper is likely to find strong support at the 21,000-yuan level unless we here some significant negative market-moving news," he added.
Shanghai physical copper was around the 20,750/20,850-yuan level due to a lack of end-user buying, traders said.
Traders said they expected copper to consolidate around current levels for the next few days.
August fell 270 to 14,550 yuan per tonne, September 300 to 14,800, October 350 to 14,950, November 320 to 15,100 and December 150 to 15,280 yuan per tonne.
Combined volume fell to 5,320 tonnes from 10,000 tonnes.
